title: Elementary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - English Language Arts (2009)
subject: Languages

document.title: Elementary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - English Language Arts (2009)

4697DF8742A3441D9B82410FBFF0ABBE.description: Written and Media Texts: Use of persuasive images, words or phrases to promote a product and/or some aspect of consumerism (e.g. on product packaging, in magazine ads, on a Web site for a popular toy such as Barbie, in a popular logo), Strategic placement of images (photo or drawing) to attract the attention of reader/viewer (e.g. as in a poster, in a magazine ad)

F52874A7562346C5A73C203AA8C40B02.description: Structures and Features The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge to construct meaning/message when reading, viewing, writing and producing texts.

2D190FA3E7094AD687E39BC37F29C862.description: Writing and Media Production The student writes/produces persuasive texts that promote a product, event or service aimed at children, specifically: Promotional posters or flyers (e.g. for a special event at school or to advertise a favorite game), Packaging (e.g. for a new toy, cereal box, video game), Ads (e.g. for a children’s magazine, for a commercial), TV and/or movie reviews for peers or younger children

408426CAA7F9441FBFBFF4DF249C23A0.description: Reading and Listening (written and media texts) The student reads/views persuasive texts that encourage people to purchase something, partake in a special activity or adopt a particular viewpoint, specifically: Popular signs and symbols, such as logos of popular food chains, clothing Packaging for popular products aimed at children (e.g. cereal boxes, toys, clothing), Promotional posters or flyers iv. TV commercials aimed at children, Magazine and newspaper advertisements (i.e. in children’s magazines), TV and/or movie reviews aimed at children (e.g. a movie trailer for a popular film or a TV show), Public Service Ads and posters created for children

9F0985E178634A0EA6BC9F046AA8F52A.description: Speaking : The student produces spoken persuasive texts, specifically: Texts that seek to persuade peers to change their habits and/or actions and/or behaviours (e.g. appeals concerning the impact of plastic bottles on the environment)

C3654CB7FFF1416C9C0AC91279941F0A.description: Media Texts: Headline or title to indicate contents, Images/ visuals to contribute to description of events, details, or impressions (e.g. in a nonfiction article on plant-eating dinosaurs, a brochure describing the school community, a blog about puppy mills), Images/ visuals to classify and sequence details, recounts, events and information (e.g. in a photo essay, in a local news story, on a website)

A473899F8AA04D7E81FAF3FBDCE11595.description: Written texts: Title to indicate contents General statement about the topic in opening paragraph (e.g. Dogs are mammals), Logical sequencing of details, facts, opinions based on events and/or information, Subheadings and paragraphs to group and/or categorize information, Use of comparison and contrast, Visuals and/or graphic organizers to extend content of written text (e.g. pictures, labels, diagrams) Summary of events, observations, impressions to highlight what is most important, Specific features of different formats depending on topics and purposes (i.e. a science report has different features than a news article describing the school community)

839695FF3AED40098132128CC2771837.description: Structures and Features The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge when reading, writing and producing descriptive reports.

BBCBF0F6F6E2433BA22502DEB5056214.description: Writing and Media Production: Reports on personal experiences in family, classroom, or school (e.g. an anecdotal report). Reports on topics/subjects of personal interest (e.g. short nonfiction texts, magazine articles), Reports about their classroom or local community (e.g. in a class or school newspaper, on a class Web site or in a class blog)

61227D1C00E746A6849189DB27A7801D.description: Reading, Viewing and Listening (spoken, written and media texts): Nonfiction that describes and reports details about a topic (e.g. simple science trade books written for children), Articles in children’s magazines that report (e.g. on a topic, event) Letters that describe or report (e.g. a character’s letter that describes an experience or event), Local and national newspaper articles that are appropriate and accessible to children,, Local and national radio and television news reports that are appropriate and accessible to children, Web pages, blogs and Internet sites appropriate and accessible to children (e.g., short video clips)

8570FA772F084578B7425240F1862C2F.description: Speaking The student produces: a. spoken reports based on family, community or school experiences (e.g. field trips, favourite toys, special holidays), spoken reports that describe the way things are or were (e.g. an observed event such as a solar eclipse, the stages of an experiment and what was observed, a report on a topic or issue of personal interest, such as the extinction of dinosaurs)

9149FB3BC2654365ABBE92BDA1EABF7B.description: Spoken, Written and Media texts: A title and a series of logical steps, in images and/or print, explaining how or why something occurs, Headings, captions or labels to focus readers’ attention on what is most important, Sequential/chronological organization of information to explain how and/or why something is done in the way it is, Images (photo or drawing) and text features that provide additional information or contribute to the organization of information. Navigational aids such as table of contents or alphabetical listing in longer texts, index, headings and page numbers, Bibliography (if needed)

7438FBEA3EEA43A4AFFBDB4404E866E1.description: Structures and Features The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge when speaking, reading, writing and producing texts.

6B7B4C5E1E5A4F558F66EAC627E137C2.description: Reading, Listening, Writing and Media Production: Texts that explain a process/procedure (e.g. rules, recipes, directions), Illustrated and multimedia how-to books, Texts that explain how or why something happens using a narrative structure (e.g. picture books such as The Magic School Bus, magazine articles), Posters that explain, Web sites (Reading and Viewing only)

43715CC1FAAC423FB1AE0CA02CCDDB64.description: Speaking: Directions and instructions (e.g. for a game), Explanation of a procedure or how something works, Explanation of reasons for a decision

C27D5718DB8141D386265900D2213A90.description: Written and Media Texts: Events/information in sequence (e.g. timelines, graphs), Chronology or ordering of actions to undertake, (e.g. in notes or lists), Visuals such as graphic organizers used to articulate relationship among actions or ideas, (e.g. webbing), Hierarchy of ideas/ information, (e.g. in an rough outline, diagram), Visuals/images for organizing or planning a text (e.g. arrows in a concept map to indicate linked ideas)

D6AB0B4BD63D4C5C840B7BA138D67075.description: Structures and Features The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge to construct meaning/message when writing and producing texts.

BFF91DBF8AD34ECE8F9920B14B5BE9FA.description: Writing and Media Production: The student writes/produces different planning texts, specifically: Learning/thinking logs and lists that record thoughts, ideas and information Webbing and mapping texts, such as story mapping, to represent the relationship(s) between ideas or separate pieces of information, Graphic organizers, outlines, timelines, graphs and diagrams to organize ideas and information coherently

25287CEBE6CE408691EAE6B26FD1804B.description: Speaking and Listening: Understands the use of talk to compose a first draft of thoughts, ideas, and information, Understands the use of talk to clarify the steps in a procedure or an organizational plan (e.g. brainstorming, pulling ideas together, asking pertinent questions)

6AD9E92B02FA4EADBF496750467D660B.description: Text Types, Structures and Features: Information-Based Text Types

289B11C7E41B4E4987A453E1CF96771C.description: Media texts All of the structures and features of written narrative (above) also apply to narratives in the media. In addition, the student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when viewing and producing media texts. Plot structure and features Use of images (photos or drawings) to extend the story and to provide story details, Use of music and/or sound to create suspense, mood, humor, conflict, etc. (Viewing only); Use of colour to suggest emotion, to create mood, etc. Use of different scenes or episodes to move the story forward (Viewing only); C haracterization Surface appearance of a character (e.g. clothing, physical attributes), Use of details to convey an imaginary character (e.g. wings, exaggerated or invented facial features), Use of explanation marks and speech bubbles to show thought and dialogue, e.g. in comic books or some animation films, Use of body language and gesture to convey character traits, including emotions (Viewing only), Use of music and/or sound to signal or stress some aspect of character, e.g. music to signal the reappearance of a character such as Tinkerbell or Captain Hook in Peter Pan (Viewing only), Use of camera angle (e.g. use of low angle to make someone look stronger or like a bully, high angle to make someone look weaker or vulnerable), Stereotypes of individuals and groups (e.g. perceptions about gender in comics and picture books) (Viewing only); Setting Repetition of symbols, or motifs, to create mood, suspense, sense of continuity (e.g. scenes of the ocean in a story that takes place in Cape Breton) (Viewing only), Use of light and dark (e.g. to create a sense of foreboding, to change time frame) (Viewing only), Clothing and other details that create a sense of time and location

8D0343E08A6745B8B6798553BF1C1EFA.description: Spoken and Written Texts: Plot structures and features- Predictable story patterns, Sequence of events, Incidents (e.g. actions that take place in the story usually related to the main conflict); Foreshadowing, i.e. the use of hints or clues to suggest what will happen later in the story (Reading only), Flashback (Reading only), Episodes, e.g. typically the subject of a chapter (Reading only), Conflict, i.e. central problem around which a story is typically organized. Examples would include man against man, man against nature, issues involving what is right or wrong, etc., Resolution of conflict Theme, i.e. the central or underlying meaning or dominant idea(s) that structures a narrative. It should be noted, however, that theme is not a textual structure that every reader interprets in exactly the same way. Characterization- Main character in a story; Stock and/or flat characters, i.e. characters with only one or two qualities or traits. Stereotypes, such as the mean stepmother, are examples of flat characters., Archetypes, e.g. the hero/heroine archetype, the villain, forces of good and evil such as superheroes (Reading only); Setting-  The physical landscap and social context in which the action of story occurs, i.e. its time and place and  Descriptive details that construct the world of the story (e.g. the forest in Max’s room allows the reader to move into the story); Other features of narrative- Literary conventions (e.g. "Once upon a time" in a fairy tale, moral in a fable), Humor, suspense, repetition and Dialogue, e.g. to reveal character, Point of view, i.e. narrative voice in first or third person

80E2324297D74851B7597138F6653A8F.description: Structures and Features: The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading, listening to and producing spoken and written texts.

C8DBE77A7F0E4E6CBEE8F17CA16FEDDF.description: Writing and Media Production: Stories based on ideas, experiences and events,. Illustrated narrative in comic strip using own drawings, images or photos , Illustrated picture books using drawings and/or images and/or photos, Photo stories (e.g. sequencing photos and/or images to create a scene from a story)

77FD8F6027FB40399AC052A8538A421C.description: Reading and Listening (written and media texts): Children’s literature: Illustrated wordless and picture books written for younger children, Illustrated wordless and picture books written for older children with more sophisticated concepts, language, issues, characterization, etc,. Poetry Classic and modern fairy tales, Early/beginning chapter books,; Young adult literature: Age appropriate popular, contemporary fiction (e.g. novels, poetry, graphic novels), Media texts Comic strips, Stories in children’s magazines, illustrated picture books, online talking books (i.e. that combine spoken word and print), Age appropriate films, video clips, animation, Nonfiction (written and media): Biographical picture books of increasing sophistication, Articles in children’s magazines or online Web page (e.g. about a sport star, civil rights activist), Memoir in a variety of text types

97DD9142A5D64156B2E034CDFA3DE74A.description: Speaking: The student produces own stories, as well as dramatizations of others’ stories, through: a. Role-play involving character from own stories, from literature and from nonfiction and Storytelling

8F8C9952490D41CD9C56C5523AECB13E.description: Text Types, Structures and Features: Narrative and Literary Text Types

00E51DD77B124375A04A2F3F554CA212.description: Writing and Media Production: Self-expressive language to relate ideas, feelings, experience Word choice to indicate a specific time frame (e.g. past tense to indicate a memory), Synthesis of ideas and feelings to focus on what is most important

564BCC4F30B845F3A21DA9A4B9665027.description: Structures and Features: The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge when reading and writing/producing texts

F5DC780CDC164441A25DE8D668C60E77.description: Speaking: Texts that focus on reflecting and evaluating own learning, in reading/ writing/ production conferences, including sharing of Integrated Portfolio

70D370BB26A5486288239A66D7DD5D5D.description: Reading, Writing and Media Production" Salutation, body and closing in a friendly letter, Relevant details such as time, place and location in an invitation Suitable message, given the communication context, in thank-you notes and greeting cards , Images (photo or drawing) to respond to the reader’s expectations and/or needs (e.g. the illustration on a thank-you note or invitation), Self expressive language to relate ideas, feelings, experiences (e.g. in own poetry), Self-expressive language in poetry: line breaks or stanzas, images, figurative language to create vivid pictures.

6CE6E9CD036B4D7FBFAFDA0F93BEFFCE.description: Reading, Listening, Writing & Media Production: Thank-you notes, Invitations, Greeting cards, Friendly letters Poetry of different kinds written by and for children (e.g. free verse, list poems, rap, shape poems, free verse)

F47E1069065B4191B35B3CB8775CFB58.description: Speaking: Formal and informal thank-yous, expressions of appreciation and support and Formal and informal introduction (e.g. of a guest speaker)

4DB874D552B44D28A8E139EBC92E7119.description: Texts That Reinforce or Maintain Relationships With Others

BDFF35687BC546E09E6CD97DE564E095.description: Text Types, Structures and Features: Self-Expressive Text Types

176A98518D9F44CDA2121D8EF938977C.description: Evaluates the effectiveness of the text given audience and purpose

CA82F74128A4480B9436EA0443E33814.description: Considers feedback from peers and others

78815B981C564C04AC23AF9309095951.description: Reviews images, records narration, adds titles or text, adds transitions, depending on the production and its message/meaning

0AE0646C4CEA479186272E8EA590F1E6.description: Uses appropriate technology resources for the specific production as needed (e.g. downloading digital images for a multimedia picture book, using a still or video camera, adding visual effects and/or animation to a comic strip)

E79B1F853A0D4D62A86B8CDDD7C25507.description: Uses storyboard and/or other planning resources to guide production of the text

46CAC8AF0CD94E5A82EF4796956C8845.description: Uses images and/or print and/or sound to produce a familiar media text

8FF7EE93AFB14F4F8CF763F50BD98071.description: Uses prior knowledge of media text type from experiences with similar texts, immersion into text

4C7317CC7944436F8569ACCECAE80C2F.description: Determines criteria for production of a familiar text type (e.g. features of an effective poster or PSA, target audience)

2C4A45CCD2234EA5ADFF46729C87FD0F.description: Identifies and gathers material, resources, expertise for the production

A6A93AA1DDBD4DE99A1B96407D32F4A1.description: Drafts storyboard (i.e. a plan or representation of the project)

EC8740BE84D941E7A2EC27383F493506.description: Examines models of text type to be produced through immersion into the type (e.g. unique features of a text, target audience, how message/meaning is communicated)

4994E4BF918A4B8097BC912AE37F9BE3.description: Selects text type depending on purpose, audience and context

5179F369E41147BCBE39B5720E83A786.description: Understands the purpose for the production (e.g. to sell something, to influence the way people think, to give information, to entertain)

CE9C100E5339450E978FE23B3173C745.description: Feedback: seeks and provides throughout all stages of the writing process

4B9A58487F834FF8A24AE1561FB3CC42.description: Selects layout and highlights relevant structures and features to enhance the presentation

A06EBA42C77442C0810C500BBC4B0393.description: Selects personally significant pieces of writing to publish

A41D78CB65C84A3BA44EA67B0FBD4580.description: Rearranges sentences and paragraphs for clarity and effect

98074C25432441BE8A70549D807954B6.description: Checks for spelling, punctuation and capitalization

7BE1587978D6492B9FDF871128DBB02D.description: Editing, i.e. rearranging/re-ordering what has already been written and proofreading

BA1F8FEAF7B54D2283DD05A11BCFFB8F.description: Adds descriptive words and sufficient details

A1D5C98DB0C648358A9AD7E22E5FAB68.description: Revision, i.e. making changes to content of text and/or message and/or meaning

1599B788FBD54F178A8DF757A46D871F.description: Connects needs and expectations of a specific audience to writing decisions (e.g. provides additional details or information, sequences events or information to enhance reader’s comprehension)

732E933862B8430F9D50D1D396C57449.description: Adjusts writing decisions to purpose and audience (e.g. the register and syntax of a postcard, flyer and letter are different)

1322DCCA0F20427489D9D53079D0B353.description: Uses a structure that fits the type of writing (e.g. letter format, narrative)

7BA1F79F4E9B46208D98472CFC18F194.description: Writes to a specific wider audience on self-selected and assigned topics, issues and concerns

BBDC2C992D3B496195CA5BF04EFECE2C.description: Writes to a specific familiar audience of family, friends and teacher

5E214DAE6C0942ECBAD7E9CB392E0FB2.description: Drafting, i.e. initial version(s) of texts

278FAB6E42274A16BBCA7560B036D486.description: Examines models of text type through immersion into the text (e.g. features of text, strategies author used to craft the text)

8E78454C9F484330A9AA9E7CE358F833.description: Selects topic and text type based on purpose and audience

C0412F6D7ADA48F4A3760B1FE2E892E1.description: Understands the purpose for the writing (e.g., to entertain, to inform, to communicate)

0F270890BBE646EC9E5EF1BE2C74C745.description: Understands that texts must be questioned, since they are constructed by people with specific purposes in mind: Determines the specific or target audience by selecting details from the text (e.g. a magazine ad all in pink is probably targeting girls), Identifies and locates information about who wrote the text (i.e. its writer/producer) and why (i.e. the purpose), Examines how the message attracts and holds the reader’s/viewer’s attention, Distinguishes fact from opinion, and real from imaginary, Considers who/what has been left out of the text and why this might be, Identifies some of the ways that the author/producer has tried to influence the reader/audience

420C551861234E67888239ED7DA9E210.description: Understands that all spoken, written and media texts are constructed by people to appeal to a specific or target audience

B31935D570C8483D94C14C64DF89347D.description: Uses other readers’ interpretations to clarify and extend own ideas (e.g. discusses information, ideas and new insights with peers)

11005FC80F4447BDA2596B3BFA557526.description: Uses evidence to distinguish between own thinking, values and beliefs and those presented in the text (e.g. figures out what values are important to a character)

670745FB20724D55842678B189A00662.description: Integrates new information with what is already known to construct meaning

57F003EF6DA04068AF6D158FE6780010.description: Uses details and evidence in the text to infer meaning(s)

662FA0E283EE481881075BBFA4765C4A.description: Constructs a personal response to the text (i.e. constructs meaning)

9320BE4DDDD24615B7A48F57ADC2C67F.description: Uses the purpose for reading and clues in the text to determine important aspects of a text (e.g. nonfiction features that signal importance such as boldface print, italics)

0EF5E53961B846A58571D65917CBD2A5.description: Recognizes the most common rhetorical conventions of information-based texts to build meaning, namely: Description of ideas and concepts, Sequence/chronology ,Compare/contrast, Problem-solution, Cause- effect.

4D9BC7F2210F489DAEF30B64ED175029.description: Relies on common structures and features of media texts to construct meaning

E1A0FED5B26641E38E24E5F8CAC3DA44.description: Relies on common structures and features of literary, popular and information-based texts to construct meaning (e.g. narrative structure: beginning, middle, end; or a feature such as dialogue)

AC80959F4B034FB6A2E8757AC288055C.description: Uses a variety of reading strategies to make meaning of different text types

5BB131393FC54DB6AFB4C72853A7AC8E.description: Applies knowledge of cueing systems to construct meaning

95586DB11BD94E13A959139C316AB902.description: Makes explicit connections between own personal experiences and story experiences

630A36CC817F4AE68ADBFF567784FA1F.description: Builds needed background knowledge and experiences (e.g. of content, setting and/or author, in a variety of ways such as watching a documentary on a related topic, reading a picture book on a similar theme before reading a chapter book, using the Internet)

C06B7E5887EC4DE18D58BB37F10470B7.description: Uses knowledge of the genre/text type to be viewed/read: immersion into models of the text type to determine important structures and features of the text type, and how these contribute to meaning in the text (e.g. understands the structure and features of familiar text types such as main character, sequence of events in narratives [stories]; visual features in information-based texts)

372CEC5631584933A8DDBED4B250E117.description: Previews the text (e.g. attends to the cover, dedication, title page and author’s notes for clues that will add to understanding or enjoyment of the text)

AA7A7EFCD6364B2BB5C0ABFAA8F5040C.description: Uses prior knowledge (e.g. what s/he already knows about the topic, author, genre/text type)

9AC4B1570EB64E9AB3272B04997B0017.description: Understands the purpose for reading, listening to and/or viewing (e.g. for enjoyment, to learn something, to escape to new places, for instructions)

661A9ABF646047FCB9A08BE3B012C912.description: Visuals that convey information and/or ideas, such as timelines, graphs, graphics in comic books

EB60FC58482946339A7B5C6E8CCEF8F8.description: Sound—in television, movies, some commercials (e.g. scary music indicates suspense)

F3804AF5B79C45BD9E102089326F086D.description: Uses and interprets camera techniques, such as camera distance (e.g. long and medium shots, close-ups)

A365050B9798461AA97651A0B5B743B7.description: Uses and interprets the visual element of perspective in illustrations or drawings (e.g. to connote a viewpoint, as in a faded, distant image that evokes a memory)

151DBF53C4524276AD748493125147E1.description: Uses and interprets the visual element of color (e.g. dark reds and blacks in a picture book to show anger or fear)

9728CE8080234CB4886F7E0EFF3CED53.description: Spelling : Indicates words that are misspelled, Applies common spelling patterns/generalizations including: word families, regular plurals, prefixes, suffixes, irregular plurals, words ending in –y, doubling final consonant, Uses resources to correct own spelling (e.g. environmental print, word lists, dictionaries, peers, spell check).

BFBE4F4989184DD3813361D0AB371DC3.description: Punctuation: Applies end punctuation rules: period, question mark, exclamation point, Applies rules for commas: items in a series, greetings, Uses apostrophes to punctuate contractions and singular possessive, Uses quotation marks to punctuate dialogue.

C4D009DB70B54FBB99E4E32AAE6D0C21.description: Capitalization: Applies capitalization rules: the first word in a sentence, proper nouns

1A5297F12ED54EC08E3BA002949F38F1.description: Uses literal and figurative language in a variety of ways (e.g. imitating, creating new words, rhyming)

2E0F570365A3461BB12610CD868A8D78.description: Selects words that convey the intended meaning and create a picture in the reader’s mind

A0AEA913423E4C75ACE9B964C4CE1F2F.description: Uses consistent verb tenses and correct pronoun references

14BBCE58955449CC87730A0D9F4991DA.description: Uses vocabulary and/or terminology related to the type of writing

FB9232771AD541148865A32508A68FF2.description: Uses linguistic structures and features to express thoughts, ideas and information for a specific purpose and audience: In simple sentences by using subject, verb, modifier In syntactic structures that carry meaning, (e.g. the structure of a question, an apology, a request). In compound sentences by using prepositions, conjunctions, interjections, In simple and compound sentences (i.e. varies types of sentences and uses transitional phrases).

29001E449C9646A995FC5CCA2A76024C.description: Writes sentences in an order that supports a main idea or story

43A1B5A504A84F64A6A22AE624EF1DC2.description: Understanding the Conventions of Written Language

279EB44D418E4958941C5988E30D495D.description: Conventions of Written and Media Language
